greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Least k such that the interval 100k to 100k+99 has exactly n primes.
comment: It is known that a(21)=1 and a(25)=0. Terms for n = 19, 20, 22, 23, and 24 are unknown. Glaisher tabulates the number of centuries having 0, 1, 2, ... primes for numbers up to 9000000. Glaisher's 1883 book is still in print!

a(24) does not exist because the only century having 24 primes is 0 to 99 -- the same century having 25 primes. From A020497, we see that a range of 101 numbers is required to find 24 primes. Dickson's conjecture implies that a(n) exists for n=18..23. - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Feb 24 2011
a(n) for n = 18..23 is greater than 10^10. Ribenboim discusses Dickson's conjecture in two books. - _T. D. Noe_, Feb 24 2011
reference: James Glaisher, Factor Table for the Sixth Million, Taylor and Francis, London, 1883.
Paulo Ribenboim, The New Book of Prime Number Records, Springer-Verlag NY, 1995, p. 372.
Paulo Ribenboim, The Little Book of Bigger Primes, Springer-Verlag NY, 2004, p. 250.
link: L. E. Dickson, A new extension of Dirichlet's theorem on prime numbers, Messenger of Math., 33 (1904), 155-161.
xref: Cf. A038822 (number of primes between 100n and 100n+99).
results.author: _T. D. Noe_, Feb 22 2011
